title: Drill Questions: Storybook Functions
text:
Drill Questions: Storybook Functions






WarningRemember to hand in your work â€¦






Submitting answersHonor statementClearing document memory


At any point, you can submit your answers by collecting them and uploading them to the class site.
Drill-06-storybook-functions.rmarkdown Collect your answers No answers yet collected






Link to upload site


If requested by your instructor, please identify here the people from whom you received assistance on this assignment.




If the answers that have been loaded automatically are not yours, press this button before starting your work:


Clear memory













NoteIdentifying Storybook Functions






12345678


Which of the following is not the name of a storybook function?

 d06-not-storybook

   hill() Â Â Â Â Â   ramp() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â   recip() Â Â Â Â Â    






Match each storybook function to its characteristic behavior. The function osc() â€¦

 d06-osc-behavior


 goes up and then back down to a baseline


 repeats the same pattern over and over


 starts low and levels off at a high value


 increases by the same factor for each unit increase in input








The function hillside() â€¦

 d06-hillside-behavior


 goes up and then back down to a baseline


 repeats the same pattern over and over


 starts at a low value and gradually levels off at a higher value


 decreases quickly at first, then more slowly








The function hill() â€¦

 d06-hill-behavior


 goes up from a baseline and then back down to the baseline


 repeats the same pattern over and over


 starts at a low value and gradually levels off at a higher value


 increases by the same factor for each unit increase in input








The function double() â€¦

 d06-double-behavior


 goes up from a baseline and then back down to the baseline


 the output doubles for every unit increase in input


 tells you how many doublings correspond to a given output


 decreases quickly at first, then more slowly








The function doublings() is closely related to double(). What is the relationship?

 d06-doublings-relationship


 They are the same function with different names


 doublings() tells you the input needed to reach a given output from double()


 doublings() is double() multiplied by 2


 doublings() is the rate of change of double()








Which storybook function would best describe the outdoor temperature over the course of a single day (rising in the morning, falling in the evening, repeating daily)?

 d06-temp-daily

   hill() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   osc() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â    






Which storybook function would best describe the adoption of a new technology (few users at first, rapid growth, then leveling off as the market saturates)?

 d06-adoption

   hill() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   osc() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â    
















NoteFunction Properties






ABCDEF


Which storybook functions have a positive rate of change for all positive inputs?
recip()Â Â   d06-pos-recip

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    



double()Â Â   d06-pos-double

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    



hill()Â Â   d06-pos-hill

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    



hillside()Â Â   d06-pos-hillside

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    



steady()Â Â   d06-pos-steady

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    





For the osc() function, what is the period (the input interval over which the function completes one full cycle and returns to its starting pattern)?

 d06-osc-period

   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3.14159 Â Â Â Â Â    






At what input value does hillside() produce an output of 0.5 (halfway between its minimum and maximum)?

 d06-hillside-half

   -1 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â    






For the double() function:

What is the output when the input is 0?

 d06-double-zero

   0 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â    




What is the output when the input is 3?

 d06-double-three

   3 Â Â Â Â Â   6 Â Â Â Â Â   8 Â Â Â Â Â   9 Â Â Â Â Â    




What is the output when the input is -1?

 d06-double-neg

   -2 Â Â Â Â Â   -1 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â    





For the doublings() function:

What is the output when the input is 8?

 d06-doublings-8

   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â   8 Â Â Â Â Â   16 Â Â Â Â Â    




What is the output when the input is 1?

 d06-doublings-1

   -1 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â    




What input to doublings() gives an output of -2?

 d06-doublings-neg2

   -4 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 Â Â Â Â Â   0.25 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â    





The flat() function always returns the same output regardless of input. What is the rate of change of flat() with respect to its input?

 d06-flat-rate

   -1 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   It depends on the input Â Â Â Â Â    
















NoteInput and Output Transformations






iiiiiiivvvi


The storybook functions take pure numbers (dimensionless) as input and produce pure numbers as output. To use them with real-world quantities that have units, we use input transformations.
An input transformation has the form \(a(q - q_0)\) where \(q\) is the real-world input quantity. What must be true about the dimension of \(q_0\)?

 d06-input-trans-dim


 It must be dimensionless


 It must have the same dimension as \(q\)


 It must have the reciprocal dimension of \(q\)


 It can have any dimension








In the input transformation \(a(q - q_0)\), what must be true about the dimension of parameter \(a\)?

 d06-a-dim


 It must be dimensionless


 It must have the same dimension as \(q\)


 It must have dimension \(1/[q]\) (the reciprocal of \(q\)â€™s dimension)


 It can have any dimension








Suppose you want to model oil production using hillside(), and the data shows production reached half its maximum value around the year 1970. In the input transformation \(a(\text{year} - q_0)\), what value should \(q_0\) have?

 d06-q0-oil

   0 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1970 Â Â Â Â Â   2023 Â Â Â Â Â    






An output transformation has the form \(A \cdot f(\text{input}) + B\) where \(f()\) is a storybook function. If you want the transformed function to have a maximum output of 100 and a minimum of 0, and the storybook function naturally ranges from 0 to 1, what should \(A\) be?

 d06-output-A

   1 Â Â Â Â Â   50 Â Â Â Â Â   100 Â Â Â Â Â   200 Â Â Â Â Â    






Continuing from the previous question, what should \(B\) be?

 d06-output-B

   -50 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   50 Â Â Â Â Â   100 Â Â Â Â Â    






If a quantity is measured in miles per gallon and you need to create a dimensionless input for a storybook function using the transformation \(a(q - q_0)\), what are the units of parameter \(a\)?

 d06-mpg-units


 miles per gallon


 gallons per mile


 dimensionless


 miles


















NoteRecognizing Functions from Graphs






IIIIIIIVV











Which storybook function does this graph show?

 d06-graph-hillside

   hill() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   osc() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â    















Which storybook function does this graph show?

 d06-graph-hill

   hill() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   osc() Â Â Â Â Â   recip() Â Â Â Â Â    















Which storybook function does this graph show?

 d06-graph-double

   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â    















Which storybook function does this graph show?

 d06-graph-osc

   hill() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   osc() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â    















Which storybook function does this graph show?

 d06-graph-recip

   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside()

title: QR-I Assignment 2
text:
WarningRemember to hand in your work â€¦






Submitting answersHonor statementClearing document memory


At any point, you can submit your answers by collecting them and uploading them to the class site.
Assignment-02-CH3-CH4.rmarkdown Collect your answers No answers yet collected






Link to upload site


If requested by your instructor, please identify here the people from whom you received assistance on this assignment.




If the answers that have been loaded automatically are not yours, press this button before starting your work:


Clear memory













NoteDrill for Chapter 3





Open drill questions in this document
Remember to submit your drill answers through that document. But for the exercises in the present document, use the â€œcollect answersâ€ at the top of this page.









NoteChapter Three






1.2.



Exercise 1 The following is from the Atlantic magazine article, â€œScience Is Winning the Tour de Franceâ€ (by Matt Seaton, July 25, 2025)

The gold standard of cycling performanceâ€”which boils down to a riderâ€™s ability to push against the wind and go uphill fastâ€”is a high power-to-weight ratio, given in watts per kilogram. The benchmark figure is how many watts per kilo a cyclist can sustain for a one-hour effort. Every rider now has a power meter fitted to their bike, so they know their numbers in a constant, real-time way (together with heart rate, speed, and other measurements).

The article describes the then-current leader in the Tour de France as having a power-to-weight ratio of seven watts per kilogram.

If this rider weighs 70 kg, how many watts can he generate?


 sbk-1-vsw

   49 watts Â Â Â Â Â   70 watts Â Â Â Â Â   490 watts Â Â Â Â Â   700 watts Â Â Â Â Â    





Look up the conversion factor from watts to horsepower. How many horsepower is the rider generating?


 sbk-2-ie2d

   0.066 hp Â Â Â Â Â   0.660 hp Â Â Â Â Â   6.60 hp Â Â Â Â Â   66.0 hp Â Â Â Â Â    





A horse weighing 500 kg can generate one horsepower while walking. How does the horseâ€™s power efficiency per weight compare to the champion bike rider.


 sbk-3-r7f


 Horse 7 W/kg versus human 1.4 W/kg


 Human 7 W/kg versus horse 1.4 W/kg


 Human 7 W/kg versus horse 2.8 W/kg


 Horse 70 W/kg versus human 280 W/kg







There is no conversion factor from watts to calories. Why not?


 sbk-4-ri3


 One is metric units, the other is â€œtraditionalâ€ units.


 You canâ€™t compare light-bulbs to food!


 They have different dimensions.


 Thatâ€™s wrong. There is a conversion factor.







Look up the conversion factor from watt-seconds to kilo-calories (kcal (or â€œCalâ€), the relevant unit when looking at diet). How many kcal does the rider produce when biking for one hour at 7 w/kg?


 sbk-5-nsl2

   211 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   422 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   633 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   844 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   1688 kcal Â Â Â Â Â    




1 watt-second is 0.000239006 kcal. In an hour, the rider generates 3600 s times 70 kg times 7 w/kg = 422 kcal

Itâ€™s estimated that a personâ€™s efficiency when converting dietary calories to work/movement calories is about 25%. In an hour of biking at 7 w/kg, how many dietary calories does a 70-kg rider consume?


 sbk-6-fjfk

   211 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   422 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   633 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   844 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   1688 kcal Â Â Â Â Â    





An â€œaverageâ€ adult walking at 2.5 mi/hr is said to use about 150 watts of power. For this hypothetical adult, how much energy is consumed in a 1-hour walk?


 sbk-7-fjfk

   130 Cal Â Â Â Â Â   260 Cal Â Â Â Â Â   1.5 Wh Â Â Â Â Â   15 Wh Â Â Â Â Â    





In the exercise/diet literature itâ€™s said that walking a mile consumes about 100 kcal.

Â Â   sbk-8-ywr

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    


 This is (roughly) consistent with the 150 watts of power claimed when waking at 2.5 mi/hr.





Exercise 2 Â 









The three temperature scalesâ€”C, F, and Kâ€”define zero degrees differently. This make it hard to do the conversion in oneâ€™s head.
The computational chunk that follows provides two functions, FtoC() and FtoK()









What is the change in C when F increases by 10 degrees?


 dfs-1-is4

   0.556 degrees Â Â Â Â Â   5.56 degrees C Â Â Â Â Â   -5.56 degrees C Â Â Â Â Â   5.56 degrees F Â Â Â Â Â    





What is the rate of change of C with respect to F?


 dfs-2-krod


 0.556 degrees C


 1.8 degrees C


 0.556 degrees C / degrees F


 1.8 degrees C / degrees F







What is the dimension of the rate of change of C with respect to F?


 dfs-3-owe


 dimensionless


 ğ›³


 ğ›³-1


 ğ›³-2




















NoteDrill for Chapter 4





Open drill questions in this document
Remember to submit your drill answers through that document. But for the exercises in the present document, use the â€œcollect answersâ€ at the top of this page.









NoteChapter Four






3.4.5.



Exercise 3 Â 

Consider the data on the body mass (kg) and brain mass (gm) for 62 species of mammals shown in FigureÂ 1. (You can hover the cursor over a point to see the species name.)








FigureÂ 1





The lessor short-tailed shrew has both the smallest body mass and brain mass. What is the brain mass of the short-tailed shrew? (Pick the answer thatâ€™s closest.)


 msp-1-4lse

   0.03 gm Â Â Â Â Â   0.14 gm Â Â Â Â Â   0.52 gm Â Â Â Â Â    





The water opposum, arctic fox, nine-banded armadillo, and rock hyrax (in the middle of the cloud of points) all have about the same body mass. What is that body mass? (Pick the answer thatâ€™s closest.)


 msp-2-sddo

   1-2 kg Â Â Â Â Â   3-4 kg Â Â Â Â Â   6-7 kg Â Â Â Â Â   8-9 kg Â Â Â Â Â    





Which of these animals has a body mass closest to 10 kg?


 msp-3-fhsl

   raccoon Â Â Â Â Â   baboon Â Â Â Â Â   roe deer Â Â Â Â Â   vervet Â Â Â Â Â    





Of the mammals in the range of body masses from 10 to 100 kg, which has the smallest brain size?


 msp-4-le4

   water opposum Â Â Â Â Â   giant armadillo Â Â Â Â Â   goat Â Â Â Â Â   kangaroo Â Â Â Â Â    









Exercise 4 Â 

The Engine data frame, which contains measurements of many different internal combustion engines of widely varying sizes. For instance, we can graph engine RPM (revolutions per second) versus engine mass (in pounds), as in FigureÂ 2.








FigureÂ 2: Engine speed (RPM) versus mass for 39 different engines using linear axes. Applications for engines span many magnitudes: compare a small lawn-mower engine to the huge engine in a large ship.





In the FigureÂ 2, most engines have a mass ofâ€¦ zero. At least, that is how it appears. The scale of the horizontal axis is determined only by the two massive 100,000-pound monster engines plotted at the right end of the graph.
Plotting the magnitude of the engine mass spreads things out, as in FigureÂ 3.











(a)











(b)







FigureÂ 3: The engine data plotted with magnitude scales




Which of the plots in FigureÂ 3 uses two magnitude axes?


 zdb-1-8dw

   (a) Â Â Â Â Â   (b) Â Â Â Â Â   both a and b Â Â Â Â Â   neither a nor b Â Â Â Â Â    





In FigureÂ 3, there is an unlabelled vertical grid line half-way between 100 and 10,000 pounds. What is an appropriate label?


 zdb-3-k4s

   500 Â Â Â Â Â   550 Â Â Â Â Â   1000 Â Â Â Â Â   3000 Â Â Â Â Â    









Exercise 5 Food and medicine are measured over a large range. For instance, in the metric system, measurements might be denominated in micrograms, milligrams, grams, kilograms. How many orders of magnitude (that is, factors of 10) are spanned from micrograms to kilograms.

 asm-1-wels

   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â   6 Â Â Â Â Â   8 Â Â Â Â Â   9 Â Â Â Â Â   10 Â Â Â Â Â   12

title: Weekly Materials
text:
CautionDevelopment Note:





This is where we will list the readings, assignments, quiz days, and other components for each class session. The formatting is subject to change.



This page provides an archive of the topics, class materials, and homework assignments used in the course. This page is kept up-to-date throughout the term.







CautionRemember to hand in your work!





Much of your work for the class will take the form of completing interactive web documents. Near the top of each such document, there is a highlighted box very similar to this on. To hand in your work, open that box and press â€œCollect your answersâ€. This will copy your essay and multiple-choice answers to your clipboard, in preparation for uploading them to the courseâ€™s collection site.
After pressing **â€œCollect your answersâ€* to the the follow the link to upload site. This leads to a Google form providing space for your email address and for pasting your answers from the clipboard. The same link will be used for the entire course.
Finally, press the â€œSubmitâ€ button on the Google form. Done!






TipMore details about the submission process â€¦





Please do not edit the clipboard string. Itâ€™s intended for computer-to-computer communication and will look something like this.
{"docid":"One-minute.rmarkdown","MC":[],"Essays":[{"itemid":"1-min-week1-a","contents":"The class was great!"},{"itemid":"1-min-week1-b","contents":"Even better today!"}}
There may be many empty fields in the string; that is as it should be.
So long as you are using the same browser on the same computer, your answers will continue to appear in the web document each time you open it. (DONâ€™T CONFUSE THIS with submitting your work. For us to receive it, it has to be submitted via the Google form.) You can go back to the web document whenever you like. So feel free to do your work in stages, perhaps spread over a couple of days.
When in doubt whether your work has been submitted, submit it again! The computerized collection system will take care of any duplications.












NoteEvery week






One-minute essays. These should be submitted by end of day (11:59 PM) after every class meeting.
A Quiz will be given once per week at the first class meeting of that week. Usually this is Monday (for section 001) or Tuesday (for sections 003 & 004).Quizzes will be short (under 10 minutes) and delivered in-class.







Reading: Chapters 1 and 2 of the QR-A textbook. Answer the Reading Questions for Chap-1 & Chap-2. In later weeks you will be asked to submit these before your class session.







TipAssignment 1






Link to assignment document
Quiz: Mon Jan 12 or Tues Jan 13. Note that this is before the submission deadline.
Submission deadline: Start of your class Wed Jan 14 or Thurs Jan 15.









Quiz covering Week 1 material in your Mon/Tues class.
Mon/Tues Reading: Chapter 3 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.
Wed/Thurs Reading: Chapter 4 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.





Quiz Mon/Tues covering Chapter 3 & Chapter 4.
Mon/Tues Reading: Chapter 5 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.







TipAssignment 2






Link to assignment document
Submission deadline: Start of your class Wed Jan 21 or Thurs Jan 22.









Quiz Mon/Tues covering Chapter 5.
Mon/Tues Reading: Chapter 6 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.
Assignment 3: Link to assignment document

Submission deadline: Start of your class Wed Jan 28 or Thurs Jan 29.

title: UATX Quantitative Reasoning - Analysis
text:
This is the course homepage for UATX INF 1130 (Quantitative Reasoning I). All course materials can be found through this website, and information will be updated throughout the term. This site is designed for students, but visitors are welcome. General information for visitors is available via the About page.
A typical class week consists of one or two of the topics from the textbook and includes textbook readings, homework questions, and a short weekly quiz.

title: QR-A Week 1 assignment
text:
WarningRemember to hand in your work â€¦






Submitting answersHonor statementClearing document memory


At any point, you can submit your answers by collecting them and uploading them to the class site.
Assignment-01.rmarkdown Collect your answers No answers yet collected






Link to upload site


If requested by your instructor, please identify here the people from whom you received assistance on this assignment.




If the answers that have been loaded automatically are not yours, press this button before starting your work:


Clear memory















NoteChap 1: Models















NoteChap 2: Quantities



















NoteChap 1: Models





System
Quantity, Variable, and Operationalization
Model & Purpose & Representation
Constant









NoteChap 2: Quantities





Per
Space
Dimension: Base and derived
Units: Base and derived
Incommensurate
Conversion factor & Flavors of one
Dimensionless
Capita
Analysis













NoteChap 1: Models






Exercise W1. 1 Many people experience the symptoms of a housing shortage: splitting up apartments to accomodate roommate groups; financial stress due (in part) to high rents; deferring life decisions such as having children; living in deteriorating, aging buildings, and so on.
Weâ€™re used to thinking about people in terms of lifespan, but it is also useful to think about buildings that way. City and local governments keep detailed information about the housing stock, largely for tax purposes. Services like <zillow.com> have data readily available to the public.
Question: What about the houses listed on Zillow might presented a view biased to houses in better condition?


A life-cycle assessment of a sample of US houses and apartments by Aktas and Bilic (2012) produced the following graphic about how long houses and apartments remain habitable.






Figure W1.Â 1: â€œLifetime distribution of residential buildings calculated from multiple American Housing Survey microdata,â€ from Aktas and Bilic 2012.



Question: Is the graph consistent with the claim that 7% of US housing stock was built before 1920?


Question: Speculate on what might account for the rightward shift of the curve over the ten year period considered. Consider these two hypotheses:

house building techniques have been improving. (When would they have had to improve to produce the curve shift?)
the current housing shortage has resulted in buildings being used after the time that they would have been replaced were there no housing shortage?







Exercise W1. 2 Consider this simple, made-up mortality table that might be representative of a bird species, e.g.Â robins.



Age
Mortality
Starting Population




0

1000


1
0.50
500


2
0.50
250


3
1.00
125


4

0



Calculate the life expectancy for these birds. Give a number, but also explain you reasoning in words. (Hint: Itâ€™s not a long calculation.)





Exercise W1. 3 Short classroom discussion about the SIR model graphic including:

a quick demonstration (narrated by the students) of the patterns seen for different settings of the parameters.
speculate on how to operationalize â€œsocial distance.â€
reason why the isolation parameter only goes up to 50%: the behavior doesnâ€™t change much for higher isolations. Explain that % for isolation means the fraction of the infectives who isolate or, equivalently, how much of the time infectives isolate.












NoteChap 2: Quantities and what else





Is there something here?

title: QR-A Week 1 assignment
text:
NoteChap 1: Models






Exercise W1. 1 Many people experience the symptoms of a housing shortage: splitting up apartments to accomodate roommate groups; financial stress due (in part) to high rents; deferring life decisions such as having children; living in deteriorating, aging buildings, and so on.
Weâ€™re used to thinking about people in terms of lifespan, but it is also useful to think about buildings that way. City and local governments keep detailed information about the housing stock, largely for tax purposes. Services like <zillow.com> have data readily available to the public.
Question: What about the houses listed on Zillow might presented a view biased to houses in better condition?


A life-cycle assessment of a sample of US houses and apartments by Aktas and Bilic (2012) produced the following graphic about how long houses and apartments remain habitable.






Figure W1.Â 1: â€œLifetime distribution of residential buildings calculated from multiple American Housing Survey microdata,â€ from Aktas and Bilic 2012.



Question: Is the graph consistent with the claim that 7% of US housing stock was built before 1920?


Question: Speculate on what might account for the rightward shift of the curve over the ten year period considered. Consider these two hypotheses:

house building techniques have been improving. (When would they have had to improve to produce the curve shift?)
the current housing shortage has resulted in buildings being used after the time that they would have been replaced were there no housing shortage?







Exercise W1. 2 Consider this simple, made-up mortality table that might be representative of a bird species, e.g.Â robins.



Age
Mortality

1000

0.50

0.50

0



Calculate the life expectancy for these birds. Give a number, but also explain you reasoning in words. (Hint: Itâ€™s not a long calculation.)





Exercise W1. 3 Short classroom discussion about the SIR model graphic including:

a quick demonstration (narrated by the students) of the patterns seen for different settings of the parameters.
speculate on how to operationalize â€œsocial distance.â€
reason why the isolation parameter only goes up to 50%: the behavior doesnâ€™t change much for higher isolations. Explain that % for isolation means the fraction of the infectives who isolate or, equivalently, how much of the time infectives isolate.

NoteChapter Six






1.2.3.4.5.



Exercise 1 Consider these four storybook functions and their characteristic shapes:

flat(): Output doesnâ€™t change regardless of input
steady(): Output increases at a constant rate as input increases

hillside(): Output starts low, gradually increases, then levels off at a higher value
hill(): Output rises from a baseline to a peak, then falls back to the baseline

For each real-world scenario below, choose which storybook function would best model the relationship between the input and output.

Input: Amount of fertilizer applied to a garden plot. Output: Crop yield from that plot. (Hint: Too little fertilizer means low yield, but too much can actually harm plants.)


 bcm-1-fertilizer

   flat() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   hill() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Years of experience in a profession. Output: Annual salary. (Assume salaries tend to plateau at senior levels.)


 bcm-2-salary

   flat() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   hill() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Distance from your house. Output: Your familiarity with the neighborhood streets.


 bcm-3-familiarity

   flat() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   hill() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Number of hours you study for an exam. Output: Your exam score. (Assume thereâ€™s a maximum possible score and diminishing returns from additional studying.)


 bcm-4-study

   flat() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   hill() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: The day of the year (1-365). Output: Average daily temperature in a northern climate.


 bcm-5-temp

   flat() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   None of the aboveâ€”this requires osc() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Amount of money invested in advertising. Output: Number of new customers gained. (Assume the market can become saturated.)


 bcm-6-advertising

   flat() Â Â Â Â Â   steady() Â Â Â Â Â   hillside() Â Â Â Â Â   hill() Â Â Â Â Â    









Exercise 2 The storybook functions double() and doublings() are closely related but serve different purposes.

double(x) tells you the result after \(x\) doublings (output = \(2^x\))
doublings(y) tells you how many doublings are needed to reach output \(y\)

Use the interactive R chunk to explore these functions.








Questions about double():

Starting with 1 item, after 5 doublings, how many items do you have?

 frb-double-5

   5 Â Â Â Â Â   10 Â Â Â Â Â   16 Â Â Â Â Â   25 Â Â Â Â Â   32 Â Â Â Â Â    




If bacteria double every hour, and you start with 1 bacterium, how many will you have after 10 hours?

 frb-bacteria

   10 Â Â Â Â Â   20 Â Â Â Â Â   100 Â Â Â Â Â   512 Â Â Â Â Â   1024 Â Â Â Â Â    




What is double(-2)? (Think: what happens with negative doublings?)

 frb-double-neg

   -4 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 Â Â Â Â Â   0.25 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â    



Questions about doublings():

If a population grew from 1 to 64, how many doublings occurred?

 frb-doublings-64

   4 Â Â Â Â Â   5 Â Â Â Â Â   6 Â Â Â Â Â   7 Â Â Â Â Â   8 Â Â Â Â Â    




A savings account doubled from $1000 to $2000. How many â€œdoublingsâ€ is this?

 frb-doublings-2000

   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   1000 Â Â Â Â Â    




What is doublings(0.5)?

 frb-doublings-half

   -2 Â Â Â Â Â   -1 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â    



The relationship between double() and doublings():
The functions double() and doublings() are related: if you know the output of double(), you can use doublings() to find what input produced it, and vice versa.

If double(x) gives output 32, what was the input x?

 frb-find-input

   2 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â   5 Â Â Â Â Â   6 Â Â Â Â Â   16 Â Â Â Â Â    




If doublings(y) gives output 4, what was the input y?

 frb-find-input-2

   2 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â   8 Â Â Â Â Â   16 Â Â Â Â Â   32 Â Â Â Â Â    




Based on questions 7 and 8, what is the relationship between double() and doublings()?


 frb-inverse


 They always give the same output


 They â€œundoâ€ each otherâ€”doublings() finds the input that would give a particular output from double()


 One is always twice the other


 They have no particular relationship











Exercise 3 The osc() function models periodic (repeating) phenomena. It oscillates smoothly between -1 and +1 with a period of 1 (meaning it completes one full cycle when the input increases by 1).
Use the interactive R chunk to plot osc() and answer the questions.









At what input value does osc() first return to zero after starting at zero?

 ows-zero-return

   0.25 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â    




At what input value does osc() reach its maximum value of 1 for the first time?

 ows-max

   0.25 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   0.75 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â    




How many complete cycles does osc() complete between input 0 and input 3?

 ows-cycles

   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   6 Â Â Â Â Â    



Modeling real periodic phenomena:
Suppose you want to model the average daily temperature in a city that varies seasonally. The temperature ranges from a winter low of 30Â°F to a summer high of 80Â°F. The warmest day is around July 15 (day 196 of the year) and the coldest around January 15 (day 15).

The average temperature (halfway between high and low) is:

 ows-avg-temp

   25 Â Â Â Â Â   50 Â Â Â Â Â   55 Â Â Â Â Â   80 Â Â Â Â Â    




The amplitude (how far the temperature swings from the average) is:

 ows-amplitude

   25 Â Â Â Â Â   30 Â Â Â Â Â   50 Â Â Â Â Â   55 Â Â Â Â Â    




To model temperature as a function of day-of-year using osc(), we need the function to have a period of 365 days. In the expression osc(a * day), what should \(a\) be?


 ows-period-a


 1/365


 365


 1


 2*pi/365







Using the average and amplitude from questions 4-5, which expression correctly models the temperature?


 ows-temp-model


 55 + 25 * osc(day/365)


 55 * osc(day/365)


 25 + 55 * osc(day/365)


 80 * osc(day/365) + 30











Exercise 4 This exercise focuses on input and output transformationsâ€”the technique for adapting storybook functions to model real-world data with actual units and dimensions.
The setup: Youâ€™re modeling the spread of a viral video. The data shows: - At week 0, essentially no one had seen it (views â‰ˆ 0) - By week 10, about half of the eventual maximum viewers had seen it - By week 20, views had essentially plateaued at 2 million
The hillside() function naturally: - Outputs â‰ˆ 0 for large negative inputs - Outputs 0.5 when input = 0 - Outputs â‰ˆ 1 for large positive inputs
Part A: Understanding the input transformation
The input transformation has the form \(a(q - q_0)\) where \(q\) is the real-world quantity (weeks, in this case).

We want hillside() to output 0.5 when the week is 10. What value should \(q_0\) have?

 rpg-q0

   0 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   5 Â Â Â Â Â   10 Â Â Â Â Â   20 Â Â Â Â Â    




We want hillside() to be near its maximum (output â‰ˆ 1) around week 20. The input to hillside() should be around +2 when week = 20. Given that \(q_0 = 10\), solve for \(a\) in: \(a(20 - 10) = 2\)

 rpg-a

   0.1 Â Â Â Â Â   0.2 Â Â Â Â Â   0.5 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â    




What are the units of parameter \(a\)?


 rpg-a-units

   weeks Â Â Â Â Â   per week Â Â Â Â Â   views Â Â Â Â Â   dimensionless Â Â Â Â Â    




Part B: Understanding the output transformation
The output transformation has the form \(A \cdot \text{hillside}(\ldots) + B\).

The hillside() function naturally ranges from 0 to 1. We want our model to range from 0 to 2,000,000 views. What should \(A\) be?

 rpg-A

   1 Â Â Â Â Â   1000 Â Â Â Â Â   1e+06 Â Â Â Â Â   2e+06 Â Â Â Â Â    




What are the units of parameter \(A\)?


 rpg-A-units

   weeks Â Â Â Â Â   per week Â Â Â Â Â   views Â Â Â Â Â   dimensionless Â Â Â Â Â    





Since hillside() naturally starts at 0 (for very negative inputs) and we want our model to also start at 0 views, what should \(B\) be?

 rpg-B

   -1e+06 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   1e+06 Â Â Â Â Â   2e+06 Â Â Â Â Â    



Part C: The complete model

Putting it all together, which expression represents the complete model for views as a function of week?


 rpg-complete


 hillside(0.2 * (week - 10))


 2000000 * hillside(0.2 * (week - 10))


 2000000 * hillside(week - 10)


 hillside(2000000 * (week - 10))















According to this model, approximately how many views would there be at week 5?

 rpg-week5

   about 150,000 Â Â Â Â Â   about 500,000 Â Â Â Â Â   about 1,000,000 Â Â Â Â Â   about 1,500,000 Â Â Â Â Â    








Exercise 5 The functions recip(), double(), and doublings() each have distinctive shapes that make them suitable for different modeling situations.

recip(x) = 1/x : Falls rapidly at first, then levels off approaching zero
double(x) = 2^x : Grows slowly at first, then increasingly rapidly

doublings(x) = logâ‚‚(x) : Grows rapidly at first, then increasingly slowly









For each scenario below, decide which function would best model the relationship.

Input: Number of workers on a task. Output: Time to complete the task. (More workers = faster completion, but you canâ€™t make it instant.)


 dcr-1-workers

   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Time since you started saving money in a high-interest compound account. Output: Balance in the account.


 dcr-2-savings

   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Amount of RAM in a computer. Output: Perceived improvement in performance (each doubling of RAM feels like a similar improvement).


 dcr-3-ram

   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Number of days since an epidemic began. Output: Number of infected people (in the early exponential growth phase).


 dcr-4-epidemic

   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Loudness of a sound (in physical power units). Output: How loud it sounds to a human (perceived loudness).


 dcr-5-loudness

   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Distance from a light source. Output: Brightness of the light at that distance.


 dcr-6-light

   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings() Â Â Â Â Â    





Input: Number of practice hours. Output: Skill improvement (the 10,000-hour rule suggests diminishing returns).


 dcr-7-practice

   recip() Â Â Â Â Â   double() Â Â Â Â Â   doublings()

title: About
text:
At the University of Austin, our students pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Studies. As part of their required course of study, students must complete a core curriculum called the Intellectual Foundations, which consists of 15 intensive courses that introduce students to the various languages of understanding and teach them to see things whole. As part of this sequence, students are challenged to confront timeless questions beginning in antiquity and culminating in the present day.
There are two quantitative reasoning courses in the Intellectual Foundation curriculum. These are:

Quantitative Reasoning I (â€œQR â€” Analysisâ€), which teaches students the mathematical modeling tools useful for modelling real-world phenomena.
Quantitative Reasoning II (â€œQR â€” Dataâ€), which teaches students to extract useful information from data using modern data science techniques.

Both QR â€” Analysis and QR â€” Data are unlike the introductory courses found at almost all other colleges and universities. We have selected topics based on their utility in modern professional work. In contrast, basic topics in the traditional curriculum reflect the historical development of mathematics rather than the needs of modern work. Modern topics widely used in the economy and scientific/technical worlds are relegated to so-called â€œadvancedâ€ courses far downstream where they are inaccessible to almost all students.
Our two QR courses dramatically streamline the pre-requisites for successful work with modern quantitative topics. Surprisingly often the â€œadvancedâ€ topics are readily accessible to students, so long as one is willing to move beyond traditional pedagogy and avoid unwarranted devotion to topics that were important historically but are no longer necessarily for understanding.

title: One-minute questions
text:
After each class session, you are expected to give a brief summary of what happened in that session as well as pointing to things that either 1) were particularly meaningful to you or 2) that you found confusing.
These are called one-minute questions to indicate roughly how much time you should spend on your answer. Of course, you are welcome to spend more time. But even if you spend just one minute, your answer should be honest, articulate, and aimed at improving the class for yourself and your student colleagues.
DO NOT write your answer while still in class.


One-minute questions

NoteChapter Five






1.2.3.4.5.6.



Exercise 1 Here are several quantities related to the function and economics of a solar power system.
For each of these system quantities, say whether the quantity is exogenous or endogenous. Keep in mind that the distinction is entirely about which quantities are connected to which. You will have to read through the whole list of system quantities to be able to say which are exogenous. Since you are not yet a solarphotaic engineer or financier, youâ€™ll have to use your best judgement about which quantities are connected as inputs to any given quantity.

latitude (degrees) of the site Â Â   cfs-1-iynwq

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



electricity price (USD/kWh) at which you can sell the power generated.Â Â   cfs-2-btuqn

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



average cloudiness (%) Â Â   cfs-3-ujkzw

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



interest rate (%) Â Â   cfs-4-jzieq

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



system cost (USD) Â Â   cfs-5-tbamv

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



area (m2) of the solar panels Â Â   cfs-6-rqlvw

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



inclination (degrees) of the solar panels Â Â   cfs-7-oecki

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



instantaneous power maximum capacity (kW) Â Â   cfs-8-txjdw

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



yearly energy production (MWh) Â Â   cfs-9-rgehu

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    



return on investment (%) Â Â   cfs-1-vclxo

   endogenous Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   exogenous Â Â Â Â Â    




Perhaps there was one or more quantities that you werenâ€™t sure was related to the others. Identify one and write briefly about which possible input quantities you were ambivalent about and whence stems your ambivalence. Or, pick one of the quantities and explain which other quantities you regarded as an input.







Exercise 2 Consider an everyday kind of question: Which is more to blame for discomfort in hot weather, the temperature or the humidity?
The blame question makes sense only if we think that humidity and temperature have something to do with comfort. Everyday experience strongly suggests that they do. For quantitative understanding, we can translate â€œsomething to do with â€¦â€ into a mathematical framework: that comfort is a function of humidity and temperature. Functions are not the only way to represent the idea of â€œsomething to do with,â€ but experience has shown that they are powerful ways to do so. Knowing how functions are constructed and how to extract information from them is an essential component of quantitative analysis.
In Steadmanâ€™s model, sultriness is constructed as a function of temperature and relative humidity. That is, the inputs to the function are temperature and humidity. The output is sultriness. You can calculate the sultriness corresponding to the values of the inputs in FigureÂ 1.











Inputs:

viewof temp = Inputs.range(
  [20, 50],
  {value: 35, step: 0.1, label: "Temperature (deg C)"}
)

viewof humid = Inputs.range(
  [0, 100],
  {value: 55, step: 1, label: "Humidity (%)"}
)


























FigureÂ 1: The sultriness function. Set the inputs with the sliders and the corresponding output is shown below.



FigureÂ 1 shows three values. When you change the inputs, the output changes accordingly. That is the characteristic of a function. The presentation in FigureÂ 1 is adequate for someone who wants to compute the sultriness for given weather conditions. We gain more insight into sultriness if we present the output of the function for many different sets of inputs. Steadmanâ€™s paper displayed the function as a printed table, which was the only practical way of communicating such a complicated function in 1979 (that is, before the widespread availability of calculators or computers).


Are there any temperature/humidity combinations at which the output temperature (that is, the sultriness index) is lower than the input ambient temperature? Â Â   gcb-1-kwe

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    



At an input temperature of 37 C (that is, body temperature) what is the highest humidity level for which the inputs are in bounds?


 gcb-2-e4kf

   60 Â Â Â Â Â   62 Â Â Â Â Â   64 Â Â Â Â Â   65 Â Â Â Â Â    





Set the inputs to 37 degrees C and zero humidity. Note the function output.

3a. Whatâ€™s the greatest amount you can change the humidity input without changing the function output?

 gcb-3a-ekxe


 9 percentage points


 11 percentage points


 13 percentage points


 15 percentage points






3b. At 0% humidity, there is some input temperature where the output temperature is greater than the input. Â Â   gcb-3b-2se

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    



3c. At 50% humidity, there is some input temperature where the output temperature is greater than the input. Â Â   gcb-3c-2se

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    




At 50% humidity, whatâ€™s the highest possible value for the output?


 gcb-4-chsle

   49 Â Â Â Â Â   51 Â Â Â Â Â   53 Â Â Â Â Â   55 Â Â Â Â Â    





At 100% humidity, set the input temperature to 20 deg C. The output will be 15 deg C. Now raise the input temperature slowly. Use the up-and-down triangles in the box showing the input temperature, so that you can change temperature by 0.1 deg C each click.

5a. How many clicks are required to raise the output temperature to 16 deg C?

 gcb-5a-oeie

   4 Â Â Â Â Â   5 Â Â Â Â Â   6 Â Â Â Â Â   7 Â Â Â Â Â    




5b. What is the rate of change of output temperature with respect to temperature at with the inputs (20 C, 100%)?

 gcb-5b-oeie


 0.4 deg C


 2.5 deg C per percentage point


 2.5 (dimensionless)


 2.5 deg C


















Exercise 3 Graphs of a function of one input, as in Figure 5.4, are familiar to many students from high school math courses. They are easily constructed with a computer. For our purposes, we use a package called {mosaicCalc} which provides several utilities for making graphics. To make a graph of a function with one input, you will need three pieces of information:

What is the function you want to graph?
What name you want to use for the input to the function?
What graphics domain you want to show in the graph?

The command to use in R/mosaic is slice_plot(). It takes two arguments. For demonstration purposes, weâ€™ll plot the hillside() function, using z as the name of the input and displaying the graph over the domain from -4 to 5.








The first argument is called a â˜Â tilde expressionÂ â˜œ, the name of which comes from the character ~. Put the input name to be used on the right side of the tilde. On the left size, give an R expression for the function you want to graph (hillside) as well as the input name to use: hillside(z).
The second argument always looks like domain(z = -4:5), but of course you need to substitute in your input name and the lower and upper bounds that define the graphics domain. These are formatted using a colon to separate the lower from the upper bound.
You are welcome to place the whole command on one line. Weâ€™ve used multiple lines so that there is space for a # comment that describes the line. (You donâ€™t need to do this.)

What R function is being used to make the plot?


 dek-1-gmek

   plot() Â Â Â Â Â   slice_plot() Â Â Â Â Â   plotfun() Â Â Â Â Â   sliceplot() Â Â Â Â Â   plot_fun() Â Â Â Â Â    





Immediately following the name of the function, there is an opening parenthesis. The matching closing parenthesis is at the very end of the command. In R (as in many computer languages) the arguments to the function are contained inside the parentheses. If there is more than one argument, successive arguments are separated by commas. How many arguments are there to slice_plot()?


 dek-2-z38d

   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â    




The first argument to slice_plot() tells which function you want to graph. In the example, the first argument is hillside(z) ~ z. This is called a â˜Â tilde expressionÂ â˜œ so named because the tilde character (~) appears.



Left
Middle
Right




hillside(z)
~ (tilde)
z




The left part of the tilde expression is a formula written in more or less conventional algebraic form. Other examples for this formula: 2*z + 3, osc(z), hillside(z) * osc(z).
The right part of the tilde expression gives the name of the input variable. In the example, the name is z, but you can use whatever name you think appropriate. Note that the formula in (i) must be written in terms of the input-variable name.
The middle part of the tilde expression is merely punctuation, but it is essential punctuation. Among other things, the tilde makes clear what are the left and right sides of the tilde expression.


Suppose that you want to call the input quantity x. You can easily modify the command to do this, just substitute x for z. In how many places do you have to make the change?


 dek-3-jwkd

   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â    




Focus now on the graphic itselfâ€”FigureÂ 2. The name of the input variable appears as a label on the horizontal axis. The label on the vertical axis, in contrast, is just a reminder that we are plotting the output of the function versus the input quantity.
The vertical scale will be created automatically by slice_plot(), taking into account the range of function output values. But the horizontal axis is different: the user specifies this. The numerical extent of the horizontal axis is called the graphics domain.
The second argument to slice_plot() is used for the graphics domain specification.

What is the graphics domain in FigureÂ 2?


 dek-4-p3n2

   0 to 4 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 to 2 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 to 4 Â Â Â Â Â   -4 to 4 Â Â Â Â Â    




In the example, the second argument is domain(z = -2:4). The graphics domain specification will always look like this, and uses the R function domain().

How many arguments does domain() take in this example?


 dek-4-7s2r

   0 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â    




There are two punctuation symbols in the argument to domain(). The colon (:) is placed between the two limits to be used for the domain. -2:4 means â€œminus 2 to 4.â€ The graphics domain zero to ten would be 0:10. The other punctuation mark is =. To the left of the = goes the name of the input variable. The expression z = -2:4 means â€œthe graphics domain of z is to be -2 to 4.

Exercise 6 The slice_plot() produces the graph of a function with one input. Convention calls for the input to correspond to the horizontal axis and the output to the vertical axis.
For functions with two inputs, the input corresponds to the points in a two-dimensional space. That is, each possible input is a coordinate pair. To graphically represent each possible input uniquely, we need to use both the horizontal and vertical axes, one for the first input and the other for the second input. Where, then, to show the output.
Our preferred graphical format for functions of two inputs is called a â˜Â contour plotÂ â˜œ. The R chunk below shows the R/mosaic code to generate a plot. Run the chunk.








This R expression follows a similar form to that used for slice_plot(). Notice, however, that the tilde expression used in the first argument names both inputs: x & y on the right-hand side of the tilde. Likewise, the definition of the graphics domain involves two components, one for each of the inputs.
It takes some practice to get comfortable reading contour plots. The labels along each blue â˜Â contourÂ â˜œ specify the output for any input that lies on the contour.
In principle, each possible input point has some contour line running through it. This is the same as saying that for each input, say, (x=1, y=2), the function has an output value. But if we drew a contour for every output value, the graph would be filled with blue ink and incomprehensible. To avoid this problem, only a handful of contours are drawn. Also, to avoid cluttering up the graph with output value labels, the contour_plot() R function labels only every second contour. The output value for the unlabeled contours are half-way in-between the output values for the two labeled contours that run side-by-side with the unlabeled one.
To illustrate, the input point (x=1, y=2) falls about half-way between the contour labeled 0.6 and the unlabeled contour corresponding to output value 0.4. Since the input point is located between the 0.4 and 0.6 contours, the corresponding output will be approximately 0.5.
In this book, we wonâ€™t dwell on teaching the syntax of the contour_plot() function. When we need it, we will give you a template so that you just have to fill in the details: the names of the two inputs, the function itself, and the extent of the graphics domain along each axis.
